Text: For the choir director. A Maskil of the sons of Korah.
Context: This is a title or superscription, setting the purpose and authorship; indicates that it is a contemplative poem by the descendants of Korah, meant for musical accompaniment.

Text: We have heard with our ears, O God; our fathers have told us the work You performed in their days, in days long ago.
Context: Recalling stories of God's past deeds; this introduces the theme of God's help in the past.

Text: to plant them, You drove out the nations; You afflicted the peoples and cast them out.
Context: Expressing thanks for God's deliverance and the establishment of Israel.

Text: For it was not by their sword that they won the land, nor did their own arm bring them victory; but it was Your right hand, Your arm, and the light of Your face, for You favored them.
Context: Acknowledging that past victories were a result of God's favor, not human effort.

Text: You are my King, O God; command victories for Jacob.
Context: The psalmist expresses trust in God as their king and pleads for victory.

Text: Through You we repel our foes; through Your name we trample our enemies.
Context: The confidence that God's help will lead to overcoming their adversaries.

Text: For I do not trust in my bow, nor does my sword save me.
Context: The psalmist professes that their trust is not in their weapons but in God.

Text: But You give us victory over our enemies; You put our adversaries to shame.
Context: Thanksgiving for the victories God has granted them.

Text: In God we have boasted all day long, and we will give thanks to Your name forever.
Context: Selah
column7: The psalmist declares their constant praise and thankfulness to God.

Text: But now You have rejected and humbled us; You no longer go out with our armies.
Context: The tone shifts to lament as the psalmist feels God's presence is no longer with them in battles.

Text: You have made us retreat before the enemy, and those who hate us have plundered us.
Context: The psalmist laments over recent defeats and the consequences they are suffering.

Text: You have given us up to be devoured like sheep and have scattered us among the nations.
Context: Expresses the feeling of abandonment by God.

Text: You sell Your people for nothing; You make no profit from their sale.
Context: The psalmist accuses God of giving them away without care for their well-being.

Text: You have made us a reproach to our neighbors, the scorn and derision of those around us.
Context: The dishonor that has come upon them is highlighted.

Text: You have made us a byword among the nations, a laughingstock among the peoples.
Context: Israel's misfortunes have made them a subject of mockery.

Text: All day long my disgrace is before me, and shame has covered my face
Context: The psalmist speaks of personal disgrace and shame experienced continually.

Text: at the sound of the taunter and reviler, at the sight of the enemy and avenger.
Context: The cause of the shame: the mocking and vengeful enemies.

Text: All this has come upon us, though we have not forgotten You or been false to Your covenant.
Context: The psalmist is confused because they have remained faithful to God and do not understand the suffering.

Text: Our hearts have not turned back; our steps have not strayed from Your path.
Context: The psalmist is asserting their continued faithfulness to God.

Text: But You have crushed us in a haunt of jackals and covered us with the shadow of death.
Context: They describe their current state as one of being crushed and overshadowed by death.

Text: If we had forgotten the name of our God or spread out our hands to a foreign god,
Context: They are making a case for their innocence by insisting that they have not been unfaithful.

Text: would not God have discovered, since He knows the secrets of the heart?
Context: They argue that God would have known if they were unfaithful because He knows all secrets.

Text: Yet for Your sake we face death all day long; we are considered as sheep to be slaughtered.
Context: The psalmist sees their suffering as being on account of their allegiance to God.

Text: Awake, O Lord! Why do You sleep? Rouse Yourself! Do not reject us forever.
Context: A plea for God to take action and not abandon them permanently.

Text: Why do You hide Your face and forget our misery and oppression?
Context: Asking for God to notice and remember their suffering.

Text: For we are brought down to the dust; our bodies cling to the ground.
Context: They express feeling low and defeated to the point of being metaphorically face-down in the dust.

Text: Rise up and help us; redeem us because of Your unfailing love.
Context: An urgent call for God's intervention based on His steadfast love.
